awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Pastoral Adaptation in Environmental Context
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to investigate the adaptive strategies of pastoralists in response to long-term drought and sociopolitical changes in the past. Ethnographic accounts of pastoralists highlight culturally specific traditional knowledge systems that incorporate animal diet and mobility and environmental factors to shape decision-making in herding practices and resource management strategies. Archaeological data, ethnographic literature, and biogeochemical analyses of animal remains can provide insights into mitigation strategies that have potential applications for informing the ecological knowledge of contemporary herders. This project employs archaeological remains to compare camelid dietary and mobility patterns across different ecological and altitudinal settings to explain how ecological and social conditions shape human-animal-environmental interactions. This project aims to provide opportunities to train undergraduate students in stable isotope analysis, a tool that has become a staple in archaeological research. 

To examine the nature and variability of camelid herding practices, this project assesses the temporal and spatial variability of herding strategies including pasturing, foddering, and mobility. It will examine inter- and intra-community variability in camelid herding strategies through stable isotope analysis of camelid remains from two pastoral settlements. The two study sites span a period characterized by changes in climate and environment, increasing conflict and political fragmentation. Carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen isotope analyses of camelid remains from residential compounds at both sites will provide insights into the variability of herding practices at the local and regional scale. Using multi-isotopic analyses of camelid bone and teeth samples, will be used to answer the following directed questions involving diet and seasonal movement. Examining forms of camelid herding strategies and their variability presents insights into localized responses to changes in regional trade networks, migration, and conflict in the past.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Herding of llamas and alpacas has a long history of resilience and continuity across time and space in the South American Andes region. However, the nuances of camelid management strategies and pastoral practices in the context of shifting sociopolitical  and natural landscapes in the south-central Andes requires further assessment. Archaeology is uniquely well situated to investigate the long-term outcomes of pastoral strategies. This study provides key insights into the ways ancient pastoral communities in the Andes maintained their camelids through different socio-political and environmental changes over the course of eight centuries.

Multi-isotope analyses–carbon (δ13C), nitrogen (δ15N), oxygen (δ18O), and strontium (87Sr/86Sr)–of camelid bone and tooth remains was conducted from eight ecologically and culturally distinct archaeological sites representing different ecological systems and political systems to examine variability in camelid management strategies. Four archaeological sites are associated with the region’s first expansive state, Tiwanaku, dating to late first millennium CE: ACH-10 (~3800 masl), Omo M10 (1120 masl), Pokotia (~3800 masl), and Wila Pucara (~3800 masl). These case studies indicate that Tiwanaku herders, whether living in the highlands or lowlands, preferentially herded their animals on highland pasture, with rural settlements showing more variable access to different pastures. The results also provide evidence for the first documented case of ancient llamas/alpacas in the highlands having been foddered with lowland, arid-adapted grasses or cultivates, most likely maize.

Another four archaeological sites are associated with the subsequent period of social and environmental instability in the region during the early second millennium CE: Chiribaya Alta (0-500 masl), Los Batanes (~500 masl), Ayawiri (4000-4800 masl), and Konto Konto (~3800 masl). Multi-isotopic analyses of animal remains from these sites reveal how herders navigated politically fragmented and marginal ecological landscapes. Highland herding communities pastured their animals across geographic expansive pastures, thus mitigating the effects of prolonged drought in the region which would have impacted nearby pastures and fields. At the same time, they would have risked confrontation with neighboring communities while also potentially benefiting from participating in broader social and economic networks. Coastal camelid herders during this time accessed grazing areas in diverse ecozones thereby responding to increasingly extreme climatic conditions including hyperaridity on the coast and periodic flood events.

This project provides insights into the resilience of pastoral communities in diverse yet marginal (high-altitude, hyperarid) landscapes. Multi-isotopic analysis of archaeological camelid remains demonstrates the forms and variability of herding strategies of highland and lowland pastoralists. This project also presents insights into localized responses to changes in regional trade networks, migration, and conflict. This study highlights the significance of examining mutualistic human, animal, and environmental interactions as reflective of indigenous knowledge. An in-depth investigation of diverse camelid herding strategies can aid in the interpretation of herding strategies in the ancient Andes and strengthen comparative studies of global pastoralism in the archaeological record.
